# Seattle–Bainbridge ferry

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Seattle–Bainbridge Island ferry [![Ferry Wenatchee enroute to Bainbridge
Island
WA.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Ferry_Wenatchee_enroute_to_Bainbridge_Island_WA.jpg/240px-
Ferry_Wenatchee_enroute_to_Bainbridge_Island_WA.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ferry_Wenatchee_enroute_to_Bainbridge_Island_WA.jpg)
Ferry _Wenatchee_ en route to [Bainbridge Island](/wiki/Bainbridge_Island
"Bainbridge Island").

Route | [Seattle](/wiki/Seattle "Seattle")–[Bainbridge Island](/wiki/Bainbridge_Island "Bainbridge Island")  
Authority | [Washington State Ferries](/wiki/Washington_State_Ferries "Washington State Ferries") (1951–present)

Yearly ridership | 6,320,820 passengers (2015)

**Connections at Seattle**  
[![Ship](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/BSicon_BOOT.svg/20px-BSicon_BOOT.svg.png)](/wiki/File:BSicon_BOOT.svg "Ship") | [King County Water Taxi](/wiki/King_County_Water_Taxi "King County Water Taxi")  
[![Tram](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Sinnbild_Stra%C3%9Fenbahn.svg/35px-Sinnbild_Stra%C3%9Fenbahn.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Sinnbild_Stra%C3%9Fenbahn.svg "Tram") | [![Link light rail](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Sound_Transit_logo_simplified.svg/16px-Sound_Transit_logo_simplified.svg.png)](/wiki/Link_light_rail "Link light rail") [Pioneer Square station](/wiki/Pioneer_Square_station "Pioneer Square station")  
[![Bus](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Sinnbild_Kraftomnibus.svg/38px-Sinnbild_Kraftomnibus.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Sinnbild_Kraftomnibus.svg "Bus") | [King County Metro](/wiki/King_County_Metro "King County Metro"), [Sound Transit Express](/wiki/Sound_Transit_Express "Sound Transit Express")  
[![Road](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Sinnbild_PKW.svg/39px-Sinnbild_PKW.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Sinnbild_PKW.svg "Road") | ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/WA-519.svg/20px-WA-519.svg.png) [SR 519](/wiki/Washington_State_Route_519 "Washington State Route 519")  
  
The **Seattle–Bainbridge ferry** is a ferry route across [Puget
Sound](/wiki/Puget_Sound "Puget Sound") between [Seattle](/wiki/Seattle
"Seattle") and [Bainbridge Island,
Washington](/wiki/Bainbridge_Island,_Washington "Bainbridge Island,
Washington"). The route was called the **Seattle–Winslow ferry** before the
city of [Winslow](/wiki/Winslow,_Washington "Winslow, Washington") annexed the
rest of the island and changed its name. Since 1951 the only ferries employed
on the route have belonged to the [Washington state ferry
system](/wiki/Washington_State_Ferries "Washington State Ferries"), currently
the largest ferry system in the United States.

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 Description
  * 2 History
  * 3 Current status
  * 4 See also

  * 6 References
  * 7 External links

##
Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Seattle%E2%80%93Bainbridge_ferry&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Description")]

This ferry route is 8.6 miles long, with terminals at [Colman
Dock](/wiki/Colman_Dock "Colman Dock") in [Seattle](/wiki/Seattle "Seattle")
and, on Bainbridge Island, at Winslow. Near the Winslow terminal is the main
shipyard for the Washington State Ferry system.[1]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Seattle%E2%80%93Bainbridge_ferry&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: History")]

Before ferries were dominant on Puget Sound, the route was served by passenger
and freight-carrying steamboats. The wooden steamship _Florence K_ served the
route for the [Eagle Harbor Transportation
Co.](/w/index.php?title=Eagle_Harbor_Transportation_Co.&action=edit&redlink=1
"Eagle Harbor Transportation Co. \(page does not exist\)"), until 1915 when
the company put the new steamer
[_Bainbridge_](/w/index.php?title=Bainbridge_\(steamboat\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Bainbridge \(steamboat\) \(page does not exist\)") on the route, and shifted
_Florence K_ to the Seattle–Port Washington route.[2]

In 1949, the
[_Chippewa_](/w/index.php?title=Chippewa_\(steamship\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Chippewa \(steamship\) \(page does not exist\)") served on the route, except
during summers, when _Chippewa_ was transferred to the [Anacortes-Sidney
route](/w/index.php?title=Anacortes-Sidney_route&action=edit&redlink=1
"Anacortes-Sidney route \(page does not exist\)").[3] From 1951 to 1968, the
main ferry on the route was the [_Illahee_](/wiki/MV_Illahee "MV Illahee")
which ran along with the [_Quinault_](/wiki/MV_Quinault "MV Quinault")
(1951-1953), [_Evergreen State_](/wiki/MV_Evergreen_State "MV Evergreen
State") (1954-1959), and [_Tillikum_](/wiki/MV_Tillikum "MV Tillikum")
(1959-1968), with the steam ferry [_San
Mateo_](/w/index.php?title=San_Mateo_\(steam_ferry\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"San Mateo \(steam ferry\) \(page does not exist\)") occasionally running as
an extra boat.[1]

In 1968, with increasing demand exceeding vehicle capacity, _Tillikum_ and
_Illahee_ were reassigned to the [Edmonds-Kingston route](/wiki/Edmonds-
Kingston_route "Edmonds-Kingston route"), and replaced by the [Super
Class](/wiki/Super_Class_ferry "Super Class ferry") boats
[_Kaleetan_](/wiki/MV_Kaleetan "MV Kaleetan") and [_Elwha_](/wiki/MV_Elwha "MV
Elwha"), both with capacities of 2,500 passengers and 160 (originally)
automobiles.[1] In 1972-1973 the Super Class vessels were displaced by the
Jumbo class [_Spokane_](/wiki/MV_Spokane "MV Spokane") and [_Walla
Walla_](/wiki/MV_Walla_Walla "MV Walla Walla"), which remained in Bainbridge
Island service until they were displaced in turn by the Jumbo Mark II Class
vessels [_Tacoma_](/wiki/MV_Tacoma "MV Tacoma") and
[_Wenatchee_](/wiki/MV_Wenatchee "MV Wenatchee") in 1997-1998.

## Current
status[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Seattle%E2%80%93Bainbridge_ferry&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Current status")]

Assigned to the route as of September 2017 were the [Jumbo Mark II class
ferries](/wiki/Jumbo_Mark_II_Class_ferry "Jumbo Mark II Class ferry")
[_Tacoma_](/wiki/MV_Tacoma "MV Tacoma") and [_Wenatchee_](/wiki/MV_Wenatchee
"MV Wenatchee"),[4] each with a capacity of 2,500 passengers and a maximum of
202 vehicles.[5]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Seattle_waterfront_pano.jpg/700px-
Seattle_waterfront_pano.jpg)](/wiki/File:Seattle_waterfront_pano.jpg
"Seattle's waterfront from the Bainbridge Island ferry as it approaches the
Seattle ferry terminal at Colman Dock")

[](/wiki/File:Seattle_waterfront_pano.jpg "File:Seattle waterfront pano.jpg")

Seattle's waterfront from the [Bainbridge Island](/wiki/Bainbridge_Island
"Bainbridge Island") ferry as it approaches the Seattle ferry terminal at
[Colman Dock](/wiki/Colman_Dock "Colman Dock")
